thread.section_title: WSJ Life, Style & Arts: Weekend News and Reads
thread.title: ‘Mr. Lear’ Review: An Airborne Life of Art and Nonsense

author: Jonathan Cott
title: ‘Mr. Lear’ Review: An Airborne Life of Art and Nonsense
text:
‘I wish I were an egg and was going to be hatched,” wrote Edward Lear in fallow middle age. Within a few years, out of the shell of himself emerged some of the most memorable nonsense songs and characters in children’s literature—the Dong With a Luminous Nose, the Pobble Who Has No Toes and the Yonghy-Bonghy-Bò. In a 2014 poll of Britain’s most beloved children’s poems, his “The Owl and the Pussy-Cat” was voted number one (with “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star” and “Humpty Dumpty” runners-up), and in 1988, on the centenary of his death, Lear took his place in Poets’ Corner at Westminster Abbey.
In...
